item.title: Report X-2024080711
item.description:
Report X-2024080711

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-09
  • City: Dulles
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Aug 8th, a package was noticed during the PM sort to be emitting a small amount of smoke and had a burning smell. After opening the package they discovered one of the smaller packages in side had burned through, causing scorch marks on other inner containers as well as a burned hole in the inner support material. The package contained cellphones, other lithium batteries as well as misc phone related accessories. The fire had burned itself out by then and the package was isolated to ensure no further conflagration occured. No injuries were reported. After the package had cooled down it was placed into a steel salvage drum and is being held pending further investigation.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Exterior packaging was torn on the seam of the box. The only label that is present on the box is the orientation arrows. Inside is a 5 gallon plastic jerrican containing a 10 kg worth or approximately 2.5 gallons of Metarom's Alcohol Booster Flavor Type Natural. There are no visible damage to the inner package. It was secured with a duct tape which held the jerrican from getting damage.

item.title: Report X-2024080595
item.description:
Report X-2024080595

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-08
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The package came out the trailer damaged on one side of the box. It was sitting on the rollers in unload when QA inspected it. After seeing one side of the box wet, QA immediately got a red tote and brought the package to the hazmat cage to be processed properly. The package contains 4 bottles of Coil Cleaner. No inner packing to stop the bottles from leaking. Possibly being on the trailer and might have tipped over. At least one of the bottles had a loose cap. Very poorly shipped out by shipper by not putting enough inner packing inside the package.

  • City: SADDLE BROOK

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ONE AIR PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED WET FROM CONDENSATION AND COLD TO THE TOUCH. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY FOUR KILOGRAMS OF DRY ICE PELLETS COOLING TWO X FIVE GRAMS OF SEMAGLUTIDE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX TO INDICATE DRY ICE WAS BEING SHIPPED AIR SERVICE. A PACKING LIST AND CERTIFICATE OF ANALYSIS IS ATTACHED TO THE BOX. OUTER PACKAGE IS PREPRINTED RUSH, INSULATED, AND PERISHABLE. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report X-2024080566
item.description:
Report X-2024080566

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-07
  • City: SALEM
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: QA personnel was called to Trailer #830652 for a potential HAZMAT package that was leaking; inspection of package verified that there was a leak of a Class 8 HAZMAT containing four individual 1 gallon jugs of sulfuric acid from the DIYchemicals/Cheboys brand. Package was isolated into a red tote and removed to the station HAZMAT cage to begin damaged package process for HAZMATs. Further inspection of the package interior verified that one out of four bottles of sulfuric acid had a loosened safety cap, resulting in the gradual spill of its contents inside the package, which remained mostly contained inside the package. Some of the cardboard box the items came in was eaten away from the spillage. There was also little to no inner packing material inside the package securing the hazardous items; there was a little bit of bubble packaging material inside, but not enough to secure the bottles, which allowed for space inside for the items to move around inside the package during transport, which resulted in damage and spillage occurring.

item.title: Report X-2024080456
item.description:
Report X-2024080456

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-06
  • City: LEWISTON
  • State: ME
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The package was discovered while offloading the first inbound trailer of the day during the start of pre-load sort at around 3:15am wet/leaking. The package was then placed into a line bin & brought to QA for processing. Upon inspecting the packages exterior, the shipping label had a "No-Air" marking underneath the ground symbol, & and a slip that contained a Safety Data Sheet for the contents inside was found on one side of the box. It was also discovered that the package did not have any Hazmat/Hazmat paperwork &/or Limited Quantity markings on the package which raised some concerns. Upon opening the package 4 1-gallon cans of Seal For Life Industries Temper Kote 1000 41 Silver Industrial Heat Coating were found soiled & with the lids popped off causing them to leak contents. 3 out of 4 were also badly bent/dented & crushed on several areas of the can. None of the 4 cans had paint clips to help prevent the lids from popping off & no packing material was inside the package to protect the cans exteriors. According to Spidr image the package appeared to be unharmed when viewing overhead images of the package at MIDD hub, meaning the package may have loaded improperly & damaged in transit as a result. When referencing Section 14 under DOT classification in the Safety Data Sheet it was discovered the contents are classified as Packing Group 2 & as a Class 3 Flammable Liquid. Several packages were leaked on as a result of the spill but were able to be successfully repacked. The portion of the leftover cardboard from the repacks were held at the QA cage to be placed into the line salvage drum per cleanup. The Improper Shipping Form & Damaged Package Report were filled out. Contents & cardboard were placed into a line salvage drum & sealed. Large rubber green gloves & blue nitrile examination gloves were used when handing the hazardous material & an additional line bin was used as a precautionary measure.

  • City: INDIANAPOLIS
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 8/2/2024 at approximately 1055, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 5156291 at the hub facility in Indianapolis, reporting a hazardous material spill. The shipment consisted of 20 plastic jerricans, shrinkwrapped and banded to a wooden pallet. One of the jerricans appeared to have been punctured at the bottom, resulting in the leakage of the entire contents. The damaged container will be sent for disposal and the remaining jerricans have been rewrapped and await an amended Shipper's declaration for further transport.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-02
  • City: DOVER
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package was found on van line appearing fully undamaged but with a strong chemical odor. Manager isolated package from sort immediately upon discovery due to strong odor, despite package not being labeled as a hazmat. QA investigated package and discovered it was an undeclared hazmat item. Outer packaging would be sufficient for hazmat item within, but is not labeled. Item was placed inside plastic bag within box, but has no additional packing material. Appears likely item moved freely within box, causing dents and forcing liquid to spill via lid seams. Leak fully contained within package.

item.title: Report E-2024080147
item.description:
Report E-2024080147

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-01
  • City: Chicago
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: SKYWEST AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Possible thermal runaway of a lithium ion battery occurred on flight AA 6271 ALB-ORD on 8/1/2024. CRJ 700 aircraft, N750SK During the flight the AFT Flight Attendant sat in her jumpseat. At some point during this action, her Electronic Flight Attendant Device (iPhone 12) slid from her pocket and into the gap behind the folding jumpseat. She stood up and realized the phone may have been crunched/damaged in the jumpseat. She noticed a crack in the device's screen. A few moments later she noticed the phone began to feel warm. She notified the FWD flight attendant of the issue. Together, they took the device to a galley ice tray and drowned the device in ice water and notified the flight deck. At that point, they realized they should be using the aircraft's fire containment bag. They moved the device to the fire containment bag and added more liquid to completely drown the device. Upon arrival into ORD, the fire containment bag containing the damaged device was handed off to a customer service agent. There were no further issues with the damaged device. PLEASE NOTE that the device DID NOT emit smoke, sparks, flames, or any gasses. This should be considered a possible dangerous evolution of heat.

QA-admin discovered package leaking and placed the leaky package inside a hazmat bag with absorbent. QA-admin then cleaned up spill with absorbent and out the cleanup absorbent inside the hazmat bag was well. Bag was then placed inside and placed inside a hazmat tote to the Hazmat Processing cage for further processing. Hazmat Package is missing OP-900 and Hazmat Certificate paperwork. So, cannot approve for HAP.

item.title: Report X-2024080599
item.description:
Report X-2024080599

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-31
  • City: LOUISVILLE
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: TWO AIR DANGEROUS GOODS PACKAGES SHIPPING WITH AN IATA DECLARATION, HAZMAT LABELS AND MARKS WERE FOUND LEAKING AT THE UPS WORLDPORT FACILITY IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY. THE SHIPMENT HAD PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACILITY, FLOWN RNO TO SDF PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT DISCOVERY IN LOUISVILLE, KENTUCKY. EACH PACKAGE CONTAINS TWO X 2.5 GALLON CONTAINERS OF VAPONA CONCENTRATE INSECTICIDE. THE ADDITIONAL TRACKING NUMBER ALSO LEAKING IN THE SHIPMENT IS 1Z0V044X0118441037. INITIAL REVIEW OF THE CONTENTS REVEALS EACH PACKAGE HAD ONE CONTAINER THAT LEAKED APPROXIMATELY ONE LITER FROM WHAT APPEARS TO BE A LOOSE CLOSURE. BOTH PACKAGES ARE ON HOLD PENDING POSSIBLE FAA INSPECTION.

item.description:
Report X-2024072499

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-30
  • City: TEMECULA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 7/30/2024 at approximately 1330, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 154002 at the station location in Temecula, reporting a dangerous goods spill. The shipment consisted of one plastic jug packaged in a FedEx padded pack. The commidity was discovered leaking from the closure, resulting in spillage that compromised the outer labeling. Based off the product name, Dangerous Goods Administration located an online safety data sheet, idnetifying the commodity as UN 3082 Environmentally hazardous substance, n.o.s.; however, the shipment was not properly packaged in strong rigid outer packaging, which voided the use of Special Provision A197. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

The shipment was placed into a steel salvage package and a new declaration will be obtained for movement.

  • City: GREENWOOD

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 29, 2024, at 0940 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Dayton Freight Lines personnel in Greenwood, Indiana regarding the release of Valspar 3168 Closure Basecoat (UN1263, Paint, 3, II). Terminal personnel reported that 3 gallons were release from (1) 55-gallon DM due to a puncture and impacted the trailer floor. Terminal personnel placed the damaged drum into a 60-gallon metal overpack, then cleaned the release using oil dri absorbents. All waste generated was containerized in (1) 60-gallon metal overpack, and (1) 10-gallon DF which was staged onsite pending disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 8500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 26, 2024, at 1247 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Dayton Freight Lines personnel in Lisle, Illinois regarding the release of GF Clean 1052 (UN1760, Potassium Hydroxide, 8, II). Contractors were dispatched, and upon arrival confirmed the release of 5 gallons of GF Clean 1052 from (1) 55-gallon DF. The release impacted the trailer floor and a 20ft x 8ft area of concrete. Contractors transferred the remaining product into a new plastic drum, then cleaned the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (1) 55-gallon DF and taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: After loading hazardous waste at the shipper's location, the Veolia operator closed the pneumatic internal valve of the tanker and proceeded to disconnect the PTO hydraulic lines when it was noticed that a puddle was forming at the back of the tanker. The Veolia operator proceeded to close the manual valve to stop the release. The generators spill response team was notified. Mechanical evaluation of the tanker revealed that debris had caused the valve stem to seize and prevent the valve from fully closing. The Veolia operator also reported that he was distracted at the end of the loading process and failed to close the secondary manual valve or place a cap on the hose.

item.title: Report E-2024080126
item.description:
Report E-2024080126

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-18
  • City: WOONSOCKET
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EQ NORTHEAST, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Material was picked up at shipper's location in morning, no evidence of any leak at that time. At 2nd stop of the day driver conducted regular inspection of lading and noticed small amount of liquid atop IBC, not leaking to floor of truck. Driver took precaution of tightening ring bolt further. At 3rd and final stop of this day no evidence of further leaking. Immediately after this incident we reached out to IBC manufacturer to inquire about different gaskets that may be better suited for package/lading. They sent a representative to our facility on 6/20/24 and it was determined the gaskets were appropriate for shipment. What was discovered was that manufacturer's original closure instructions has been changed since purchase of this container. Original instructions were 30 ft/lbs torque on closures. This was updated after the fact to 40 ft/lbs. We had a subsequent and very similar leak on 6/4/24 (before manufacturer rep arrived and updated instructions), see previous report on this event.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The incident report was filed due to spillage of Diesel Fuel from the saddle tank from the power unit. The CMV jackknifed causing the saddle tank to be crush and releasing diesel fuel on the roadway. The driver failed to maintain control of the CMV and struck a guard rail. The roadway was wet and under construction (repaving) and the surface was uneven. No other vehicles were involved and no injuries were reported. A local Hazmat clean-up company (ECOtech, 50 Easy Street, London, KY. 40741) responded to the scene. They tapped the fuel tank and transferred the contents to slow/stop the leak. The materials used were hydrocarbon exsorbent pads, absorbent booms, recovery drum, skid steer, and a dump truck for disposal.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-09T00:38:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-13
  • City: Douglasville
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Spirit Express LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 193756
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver was traveling approximately 65 MPH westbound on I-20. He was traveling in the far right lane, when he fell asleep at the wheel. He awoke to stopped traffic in front of him without enough time to come to a safe stop. The driver jerked the wheel to the right to avoid contact with the vehicles in front of him and left the road way. He overturned on a side embankment at MM-43. Upon impact of the crash, a weld in the tank ruptured as well as one of the manhole covers on the top of the trailer. The product slowly leaked out of the trailer for approximately 1 hour. Other vehicles in traffic that witnessed the incident dialed 911. The driver contacted his employer, who in turn contacted Marion Environmental who was closer to the scene and could mitigate the release of gasoline quicker and more efficiently than the carrier could themselves. They set up absorbent booms to control the spilled product. The remainder of the product was pumped over into another trailer and safely transported to the original destination.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: LOS ANGELES
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package came out of trailer 840669 in a wet, deteriorated state. Package was placed in a tote for QA. upon inspection, contents is a bottle of Decal stat that had a loose cap, causing its liquid content to spill out which in time deteriorated a small portion of the package. While the package had filling to prevent movement on the body, there was minimal to none for the cap, which if properly protected, would have not become loose during movement.

item.description:
Report X-2024080317

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package was observed to be wet when package handler prepared to unload it from trailer. QA admin was called to the scene and placed the package in line HazMat tote. Aside from this carton being wet, there was little evidence of any spill inside trailer. No other packages were affected and admin cleaned up the area where the package had been with neutralizer as a precaution. Internal bottle had a loose cap, it also presents visually as having been crushed or compressed on opposite sides of the bottle, though there's no sign of the outer carton having been impacted adversely. Though the package carton presented wet, none of the bottles inside were, and the labeling on the bottles show no sign of having made contact with corrosive mixture. Body of bottle which lost content is intact, there is no sign of leakage there.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-02
  • City: ATLANTA
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: USPS VOLUME AT RFD GATEWAY WAS FOUND TO CONTAIN ONE PACKAGE WITH LEAKING UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS AEROSOL CONTENTS. OUTER PACKAGE INSPECTION REVEALS ONE USPS PRIORITY MAIL BOX THAT HAS BEEN PARTIALLY DESTROYED WITH FOUR AEROSOL CANS OF SPRAYWAY GLASS CLEANER SPILLING OUT. INITIAL REVIEW REVEALS ONE OF THE AEROSOL CANS LEAKED CONTENTS CAUSING THE PACKAGE TO DETERIORATE. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER USPS BOX. THE BOX DOES NOT HAVE SHIPPER OR CONSIGNEE INFORMATION. PRIOR TO THE UNDECLARED DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS TRAILERED ORD TO RFD AND WAS DESTINED TO FLY ON UPS AIRCRAFT TO OAK. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.

item.title: Report E-2024080078
item.description:
Report E-2024080078

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-01
  • City: Canton
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: at 0100 hrs. while inspecting their train, the WLE Gambrinus Yard train crew, noticed tank car TILX 305022 at Gambrinus Yard leaking vapor from the top of the car. They notified the WLE Gambrinus Yardmaster who then contacted myself, John Vergis, Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE. When I arrived, I could her the car leaking vapor from on top the car. The leak was substantial, but just vapor, no liquid. I climbed the car and removed seal # 0672272 from the protective housing lid. I investigated and found no leak inside the protective housing. Upon further investigation, it was concluded that the leak was coming from the gasket connection between the pressure plate and the tank car nozzle. The pressure plate stud bolts appeared to be tight. There was no way to stop the leak. The leak was coming from the left side of the housing. I called CHEMTREC at 0127 hrs. to make a report and have them contact Marathon Petroleum in order to give me assistance. Jennifer Johnson, the emergency contact from Marathon called me at 0158 to inquire about the report. The CHEMTREC Report number was 2024080100010. I told her what was going on and that I would be calling 911 to request the Stark County HAZMAT Team. I also told her that I would be calling Enviroserve out of North Canton, Ohio to come out and do an emergency transfer of the car since that was the only way we could stop it from leaking. She agreed and had me make the calls. I called 911 at 0210 hrs. I called the Timken Steel Security folks to have them stop all traffic on their access road that parralels the location of the incident, so that they would be no chance for ignition from any of their equipment. I called Enviroserve at 0219 hrs. and briefed them on the situation and told them we needed and emergency transfer and then a flaring and purging of the car afterwards. I called the Stark County Spill Report Line at 0234 hrs. to report the incident. After we got the HAZMAT Team out and started doing air monitoring, I called to make a report with the Ohio EPA at 0505 just as a courtesy to report the vapor release. We had 7 area rays set up for air monitoring and discovered that the vapors were going straight up and not really concentrating around the car or anywhere else at ground level. No evacuations were required since the yard itself is isolated. We started to Transload the car at about 0800 hrs. We started to flare the car of its residual vapors at about 1430 hrs. and finished at 2230 hrs. The car was labeled with Do Not Load and Home Shop Stickers and was stenciled “Cleaned”.

item.description:
Report E-2024080079

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-26
  • City: MONROE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CARRIER IS AN INDIVIDUAL
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 3:32 pm on Friday, July 26, 2024, During the loading process the driver failed to secure his manway before departure. The driver, after leaving Worthington Monroe, was contacted by PVS Dispatch and subsequently stopped on the side of the I-75 freeway, at the north end of the I-275 loop in Cincinnati, to tighten the bolts on the transport vehicle. Hepaco Project Manager: Bill Swope, (463) 253-5405 Bill Swope reported that the spill on the intersection of Lawton and interstate 62 amounted to approximately 3 gallons. Hepaco, a professional environmental and emergency response company, was engaged to handle the spill. Bryan Martin, Hepaco VP, and Bill Swope, the project manager, coordinated the cleanup operations. Hepaco was dispatched to clean the spill with the supervision of the Ohio EPA, Ohio EPA: Trevor Irwin, (614) 886-2484 The prompt and coordinated response by the Worthington Monroe team, in conjunction with Hepaco and the Ohio EPA, successfully mitigated the effects of the ferrous chloride spill. Through immediate action, effective communication, and thorough cleanup efforts, the environmental and health impacts of the spill were minimized.

  • Description: Veolia employees loaded the drum into the truck at the shipper's location. During loading the drum was inspected and appeared to be in good condition. Upon arrival at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Baytown, TX the container was found to be leaking and a small puddle of liquid was under the pallet. Upon inspection of the pallet there was a nail protruding slightly that may have caused the leak via friction in transit. The spill was remediated using absorbent material and the leaking container was overpacked into a salvage drum for continued transportation to the destination.

  • Description: Circle K notified ERTS of a fuel overfill at a Mapco in Nashville, TN (Circle K bought out Mapco). It was reported that approximately 100 gallons of premium unleaded gasoline released due to the cap coming loose on the veerder-root system (measures the depth of how much fuel in the tank) when they were filling it. He has his lead driver on the way with oil dri, spill pads, and absorbent snakes and the area has been coned off. The release impacted asphalt and has spilled into the roadway, shutting down the Firestone next door. No storm drains or waterways are impacted by the release that he is aware of. He is not aware of any road closures or emergency personnel on site at this time but believes management will be notifying the fire department.

item.title: Report E-2024070638
item.description:
Report E-2024070638

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-05
  • City: BORDULAC
  • State: ND
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY (DBA Canadian Pacific Kansas City Railroad)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 19787859
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On 7/5/2024 at 3:42 AM Central Time, Canadian Pacific Kansas City Railroad (CPKC) train 242-03 derailed 29 rail cars at milepost 342.86 on the Carrington Sub near the town of Bordulac, North Dakota. Derailed cars included six loaded tank cars transporting UN1230, Methanol, 3, PG II, RQ (Methanol), eleven loaded tank cars transporting UN1005, Ammonia, Anhydrous, 2.3(8), Toxic Inhalation Hazard, Zone D, Marine Pollutant (Ammonia, Anhydrous), RQ (Ammonia), and twelve loaded hopper cars transporting non-hazmat Polyethylene pellets. CPKC mobilized internal and railroad qualified external resources to investigate the damage and mitigate released lading. Fire was reported immediately after the derailment, with multiple cars on fire. Many of the derailed tank cars experienced heat impingement. Because of this, pressure built within tank cars caused pressure relief devices to release product into the atmosphere. Additionally, releases occurred from holes and punctures in tank shells, and from damage incurred to manways, valves, pressure regulating devices, and other tank car appurtenances. The NTSB is investigating this incident and has requested that CPKC refrain from modifying any tank cars until it has completed its work. Because of this, CPKC has not been able to fully assess damage which might have occurred under tank jackets. The following information is the best information available at this time. The cars detailed below released the listed amounts in gallons from the following locations: 1) PROX 45220, loaded Methanol, Release=0.00 - minor damage to tank car did not result in a release. 2) CTCX 300362, loaded Methanol, Release=13,558.25 - heat impingement affected integrity of manway gasket (121-Gasket 308-Leaked 512-Fire, Temperature, or Heat) & pressure Relief Device (PRD) activated (144-Pressure Relief Valve or Device – Reclosing 313-Vented 512-Fire, Temperature, or Heat). 3) TILX 355610. loaded Methanol, Release=26,035.55 - tank shell was punctured on the right side between the housing and the B-End, and on the left side of the tank car directly below the housing (150-Tank Shell 309-Punctured 509-Derailment), liquid line valve separated from the pressure plate (134-Liquid Valve 312-Torn Off or Damaged 509-Derailment), PRD sheared off at the pressure plate (144-Pressure Relief Valve or Device – Reclosing 312-Torn Off or Damaged 509-Derailment), & 4/6 manway securement bolts were damaged. (105 Bolts or Nuts 312 Torn Off or Damaged 509 Derailment) 4) MFCX 132265, loaded Methanol, Release=26,526.48 - tank shell was punctured on the B-End & A-End (150-Tank Shell 309-Punctured 509-Derailment), the liquid valve sheared off at the flange (134-Liquid Valve 312-Torn Off or Damaged 509-Derailment), & the vapor valve & PRD sheared off at pressure plate (158 Vapor Valve 312-Torn Off or Damaged 509-Derailment) (144-Pressure Relief Valve or Device – Reclosing 312-Torn Off or Damaged 509-Derailment) 5) CTCX 300358. loaded Methanol, Release=27,849.02 -

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: INDIANAPOLIS
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO contacted ERTS to report a spill of an unknown amount of unknown material both inside the trailer and out onto the ground under the trailer. ERTS dispatched a contractor to assist with the spill. HEPACO was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 3ft-by-10ft area of the trailer floor and asphalt underneath the trailer and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to a crack in the metal tote from a forklift. HEPACO deployed absorbents and then swept up the released material. The tote was placed in the OS&D. The recovered material was placed into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum and was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-30
  • City: BESSEMER

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Fiberboard box containing 4 plastic bottles of liquid disinfectant. The caps on each bottle are either looses or defective, as they are able to move vertically ~1cm on the top of the bottle. 1 of the 4 was noticeably looser than the rest during inspection. Package was found with a small wet spot on the side, but the spill did not progress beyond the box. Package appears to have been on its side at some point during transportation based on the inside of the box and staining only one 1 side of the bottles. Package had not yet made it to QA for HAP processing, but all documents were present and acceptable at the time of inspection.

  • Description: This Hazmat Package was brought to attention during the outbound sort. The admin proceeded to put gloves on for further inspection. This hazmat package was leaking out of the bottom seam where the soldering point is, the leaking is slow and not obvious but residue was present on the bottom of the drum. The leaking liquid was contained from the start and no residue of any kind was found on the floor. While handling the drum, the admin placed a plastic bag in a bin to ensure safety to make sure that the leak was contained. No individuals were harmed or present near the hazmat.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 25, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately 55-gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel deployed granular absorbents and a neutralizing agent to the sodium hydroxide-impacted trailer and dock and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into four (4) 55-gallon drums. The damaged 55-gallon drum of product was placed into one (1) 95-gallon drum.

ES&H personnel arrived and discovered that R+L personnel had placed granular absorbents to the spilled product. ES&H began remedial actions by sweeping all absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon waste drum. The crew then placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 85-gallon overpack. item.title: Report E-2024070529
item.description:
Report E-2024070529

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-07T15:13:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: Lansing
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 07/09/2024, at 1300 hrs., CSX Hazardous Materials Manager Scott Karcher discovered in the CSX Ensel Yard, the GATX29637, a loaded tank car of Acetone, releasing product vapor from the vacuum relief valve (VRV). The car was isolated and the shipper, Altivia Chemical, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2024-07-09-00182). EnviroServe, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and determined the VRV was faulty. Contractor personnel removed the defective vacuum relief valve and applied a securement plug to stop the vapor release. The issue was identified, and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper's representative (Jeremy Walker, 740-533-5232, jwalker@altivia.com).

item.title: Report E-2024070378
item.description:
Report E-2024070378

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-07T15:13:00+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-04
  • City: CEDARTOWN
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 1500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Thursday, July 4th, 2024, at 1057 hours, CSX personnel operating the L81004 observed GATX 5618, a loaded tank car of Sulfuric Acid, in the train, was leaking from the protective housing. The car was held by the CSX train crew on the Main Line at MP SGC 621 outside of Rockmart GA for further investigation. The shipper, GEO Specialty Chemicals Inc, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2024-07-04-00063). Marion Environmental, Inc. (MEI), a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found the liquid line closure cap less than tool tight. Contractor personnel tightened the liquid line cap to secure the car. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Dan Parker, GEO Logistics Manager, 404-782-1699). The car was released for transportation.

  • Description: While unloading, the ring around a open head drum came off, causing the drum to drop off the pickers and land on the trailer. The drum remained upright, as it was being moved carefully and low to the floor. A small amount of waste splashed out and onto the trailer floor. The ring was able to be placed back on the drum and tightened to secure the drum. The spill was contained and cleaned up. The spill was about 8 feet from the rear of the trailer.

Upon inspection saw the cap on the one plastic 5 L container was loose and it looked like 4 oz of liquid could have leaked out of the plastic container into the box. There was no liquid on the floor of the trailer.

  • Description: shipment taken out of system flow due to external carton wet and leaking upon inspection of inner content 4 x 1 gallon plastic bottle of meritech self clean 1 x 1 gallon plastic bottle of meritech self clean had a loose cap allowing 0.10 gallons to release from container Facility procedures for damaged hazardous materials followed contents contained and awaiting disposition.
